STATE OF MICHIGAN
GRETCHEN WHITMER DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING DIRECTOR
June 14, 2021
Ellen Westgate
Catholic Social Services Of Washtenaw
4925 Packard Road
Ann Arbor, MI 48108-1521
RE: License #: CB810201018
Investigation #: 2021C0207012
Catholic Social Services Of Washtenaw
Dear Ms. Westgate:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
 How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
 Specific time frames for each violation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please note that violations of any licensing rules are also violations of the MSA and your
contract.
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  517-335-1980

Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the local office at (866) 685-0006.
Sincerely,
Kari Muntean, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
22 Center Street
Ypsilanti, MI 48198
(734) 395-0920
enclosure
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  517-335-1980

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
SPECIAL INVESTIGATION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
License #: CB810201018
Investigation #: 2021C0207012
Complaint Receipt Date: 04/07/2021
Investigation Initiation Date: 04/07/2021
Report Due Date: 06/06/2021
Licensee Name: Catholic Social Services of Washtenaw
Licensee Address: 4925 Packard Rd
Ann Arbor, MI 481081521
Licensee Telephone #: Unknown
Administrator: Ellen Westgate, Designee
Licensee Designee:
Name of Facility: Catholic Social Services Of Washtenaw
Facility Address: 4925 Packard Road
Ann Arbor, MI 48108-1521
Facility Telephone #: (734) 971-9781
Original Issuance Date: 01/01/1992
License Status: REGULAR
Effective Date: 02/08/2020
Expiration Date: 02/07/2022
Capacity: Unknown
Program Type: CHILD PLACING AGENCY, PRIVATE
1

II. ALLEGATION(S)
Violation
Established?
Agency staff member and supervisor were aware adult household Yes
member that moved into a licensed foster home had criminal
history. Thorough background checks were not completed, and
the adult remained in the home providing care to and supervising
the children.
Agency allowed an adult household member to sleep in the same Yes
room with the foster children and provide care and supervision.
Staff also compromised a DHHS investigation in this same home. Yes
Concerns that agency is not appropriately addressing issues
through special evaluations of this provider.
ADDITIONAL FINDINGS: The agency’s Special Evaluation Yes
Report lacked required information.
III. METHODOLOGY
04/07/2021 Special Investigation Intake
2021C0207012
04/07/2021 Special Investigation Initiated - Telephone
Interviewed complainant.
04/07/2021 Contact - Document Sent
Emails exchanged with complainant.
04/07/2021 Contact - Document Received
MiSACWIS complaint, foster home, and case information reviewed
related to complaint. BITS information reviewed related to facility.
04/07/2021 Contact - Document Sent
Email notification of complaint sent to CA. Documentation
requested.
04/08/2021 Contact - Telephone call made
Left message for the Chief Administrator (CA).
04/08/2021 Contact - Document Received
Email from CA.
2

04/09/2021 Contact - Document Sent
Email to CA.
04/14/2021 Contact - Telephone call made
Discussed complaint with CA.
04/14/2021 Contact - Document Sent
Emails exchanged with Licensing Supervisor.
04/14/2021 Contact - Document Sent
Emails exchanged with Licensing Worker.
04/16/2021 Contact - Face to Face
Teams video conference with Licensing Supervisor.
04/16/2021 Contact - Document Sent
Emails exchanged with Licensing Supervisor.
04/19/2021 Contact - Document Received
Email from Licensing Supervisor.
04/20/2021 Contact - Face to Face
Teams video interview with Licensing Worker.
04/22/2021 Contact - Document Received
Email from Licensing Worker.
05/13/2021 Contact - Document Received
Email from Licensing Supervisor.
05/13/2021 Contact - Document Received
Emails received from Licensing Supervisor and Licensing Worker.
05/17/2021 Contact - Document Sent
Email to Licensing Supervisor.
05/17/2021 Contact - Document Sent
Emails exchanged with Licensing Supervisor.
05/17/2021 Contact - Document Sent
Email to Licensing Worker.
05/28/2021 Contact – Document Received
Email from Licensing Worker.
06/03/2021 Contact - Document Received
3

Email from Licensing Worker.
06/04/2021 Contact – Document Sent
Emails exchanged with Licensing Worker and Licensing
Supervisor.
06/08/2021 Contact – Document Sent
Email to Licensing Worker and Licensing Supervisor.
06/09/2021 Contact – Document Received
Email from Licensing Worker
ALLEGATION:
Agency staff member and supervisor were aware adult household member that
moved into a licensed foster home had criminal history. Thorough background
checks were not completed, and the adult remained in the home providing care to
and supervising the children.
INVESTIGATION:
The complaint was received via the DCWL online complaint portal on 04/07/2021,
and I interviewed the complainant on the same day. The complainant verified the
information in the online complaint. It was reported that a complaint was assigned to
a DHHS Specialist for investigation on 03/25/21 and the investigation was being
completed jointly with the agency Licensing Worker and Licensing Supervisor.
During the DHHS Specialist’s interview with the foster parent a review of household
members occurred. The foster parent said that her adult brother was residing in the
home and the brother’s contact information was provided to the DHHS Specialist. It
was reported that the brother was called, his date of birth was verified, and a
criminal history was completed by the DHHS Specialist on 03/30/2021. The
complainant said that it was found that the adult household member (brother) had a
criminal history consisting of multiple felony offenses including violent offenses. On
03/30/21, upon learning of the household member's criminal history, the DHHS
Specialist called the Licensing Worker to inquire if this was brought to their attention.
Reportedly, the Licensing Worker confirmed that the Licensing Supervisor was
aware of the household member's felony criminal history and that he was released
from prison 3 years ago. The complainant said the Licensing Worker referred all
further questions to her supervisor.
It was then reported, on 03/31/21, that the Licensing Supervisor said she was
notified by the foster parent, on 02/18/2021, that the brother was going to be moving
into the home. The Licensing Supervisor reportedly stated that she ran a clearance
on the brother, and it yielded the felony convictions, but after a conversation with the
4

brother he stated that the convictions were for a different individual with the same
name as him. The complainant advised that she contacted the adult brother on
03/31/21, and the brother acknowledged that he had felony criminal history and
stated that he was "cleared by the Licensing Supervisor". The complainant also
reported being informed by foster care that the adult household member was
providing care, without the foster parent, for the MCI ward on 03/31/2021.
There was an emergency conference call for this case on 04/01/2021 with various
parties related to this case. The complainant said that during the call, the Licensing
Supervisor continued to question if the felony convictions were of this man or of
another individual with the same name. The Licensing Supervisor was then informed
that the DHHS Specialist looked up the offender profile on Michigan Department of
Corrections and the adult's photograph is on his profile, and that the DHHS
Specialist confirmed the history with the adult brother directly. The complainant
added that the agency said the agency never added this adult as a household
member to the foster home record and it is believed that the adult was residing in the
home/providing direct care to the foster children for at least/approximately 30 days.
The complainant further reported that on 04/01/2021, the foster parent was asked if
the licensing agency was made aware of her brother's criminal history and the foster
parent reported that the Licensing Supervisor was fully aware of the multiple felony
convictions. The complainant also reported that the Licensing Supervisor was aware
that the adult brother was sleeping in the same room as foster children and did not
correct the situation.
I discussed the complaint with the Chief Administrator via phone on 04/14/21. The
Chief Administrator was aware of this situation but referred me to the Licensing
Supervisor and Licensing Worker.
I interviewed the Licensing Supervisor (LS) on 04/16/21 via video meeting. The LS
reported that she is assigned this foster home and the Chief Administrator is her
supervisor. The Licensing Worker is assigned to the complaint on this foster home.
The LS said that she learned from the foster parent on 02/28/21 that the foster
parent had a very difficult incident with one of the children placed in her home
resulting in the police being called to the home and the youth taken for psychiatric
evaluation. The LS said that she then received a text message from the foster parent
that her brother was going to come and help her. The LS said that she was not told
that the brother was going to be staying in the home, but just helping. The LS said
that she asked for the adult brother’s information and submitted a Central Registry
clearance on 02/28/21 since the foster parent said he was going to help her with the
children. The LS said that she did not find out the brother was in the home at all until
03/03/21, when she reviewed the police report related to the difficult incident with the
foster child. The LS also stated that, on 03/04/21, the foster parent sent her a copy
of a safety plan she created herself that noted the adult brother and adult nephew
would be sleeping in the room with one of the foster children for safety reasons.
When asked who the nephew belonged to, the LS did not know and acknowledged
that she had not asked the foster parent about this. The LS said she ran criminal
5

clearances on the adult brother on 03/05/21 and noted a criminal history but
conflicting information with his middle initial and birthdate. The LS said she double
checked the middle initial with the foster parent, who said the brother did not have a
middle name. The LS also said that the date of birth was different than the
identification provided by the brother. The LS said she met with the adult brother on
or about 03/05/21 and he denied that the criminal charges on the background check
were his. He also denied having a middle initial. The LS said that she and the
Licensing Worker advised the adult brother and the foster parent that this was an
issue and that he needed to get the clearances resolved if this was not him. Per the
LS, the adult brother and foster parent were told that he could not provide care to the
foster children. The LS said that the different birth date and middle initial from the
adult brother’s identification made her unsure if the history was actually his. On or
about 03/13/21-03/15/21, the LS said that the DHHS Specialist advised her that the
DHHS Specialist ran clearances and confirmed that the criminal history was for the
adult brother and directed her how to view additional information in the public
database where there was a photo of the brother. During this period of time, the LS
said that she did not know the brother was living in the home, but thought he just
came into the area to help, as reported by the foster parent. The LS said that she
told the foster parent again on, or about, 03/30/21, that the brother could not provide
care during a telephone call. It was not until the foster care workers and DHHS
Specialist advised that he was providing care unsupervised by the foster parent that
she learned of this.
The LS provided some additional clarification on this via email on 04/19/21. The
following was reported:
The foster parent notified me indicating that she was having a great deal of
difficulty with the children placed in her home on 2/18/2021. She indicated that
she spoke to her brother, and he may be able to provide some help to her. I
indicated that she would need to provide his driver’s license and social security
card so that a central registry check and police check could be completed.
Indicated that he could not provide care to children until he is cleared.
The agency was made aware that the adult brother was living in the home
through an email that was sent at 7:19 pm on 3/4/21. Did not open email until
3/5/21. This outlined a safety plan that the foster parent developed and sent to
the foster care worker as well as me. This was not a safety plan that I assisted
the foster parent in writing.
After the agency was made aware that arrangements had been made for the
adult brother to sleep in the same room as a foster child, the foster parent was
contacted to indicate that her brother was not cleared yet.
This email went on and the LS reiterated in the email that there was uncertainty
related to the brother’s date of birth and middle initial. The LS also reiterated that
she told the foster parent that the brother could not provide care to the child. The LS
noted on 03/12/21 she had a meeting at the home with the foster parent, adult
6

brother, and Licensing Worker, where she reviewed the criminal history and the
adult brother stated that was not him. She advised the brother how to clear his
record and that it needed to be remedied before he could provide care. The LS also
emailed, “The foster parent had indicated on a couple of occasions that her adult
brother was not staying in the home all the time.” The email further stated that the
LS and LW were at the home on 03/26/21, along with the DHHS Specialist, when
the foster parent said that her adult brother would be moving out of the home and
should be gone by 03/28/21. The LS wrote that she told the foster parent that he
could not provide care and needed to be out of the home. The LS said that the foster
parent advised on 03/31/21 that he was no longer in the home.
I interviewed the Licensing Worker (LW) via video conference on 04/20/21. The LW
reported that she has received several complaints on this foster home recently.
Regarding the foster parent’s adult brother residing in the home, the LW said that
she became aware of it from the LS after the police report (from an incident in the
home) was reviewed. The LW said this is not her assigned home, so she was not
sure when the adult brother moved in. The LW said that during her visit to the home
on 03/26/21 she did not notice belongings of the adult brother’s in the home, but the
foster parent said that he was storing some things in the garage and they were to be
gone by 03/28/21. The LW said that she was aware that the clearance on the adult
brother yielded criminal convictions but noted there was a discrepancy in the middle
name and date of birth. The LW said that she and the LS asked the foster parent
and brother about this and they both said that the brother did not have a middle
name and the convictions were not his. The LW said that they directed the foster
parent and brother to clear this up before providing care to the children or being
alone with the children. The LW said that it was not until later on, 03/31/21, that they
were advised the adult brother was watching the kids when the foster parent called
the LS while running an errand and told the LS that the adult brother was watching
the kids.
Documentation reviewed as part of this investigation is as follows, with applicable
information noted:
 MiSACWIS review of the foster home information
o Household members did not include the adult brother, nephew, or son
 Safety plan email from foster parent sent to LS: dated 03/04/21 and noted
that her adult son, adult brother, and adult nephew were in the home with her
due to the difficulties with one foster child’s behaviors. This plan noted that
the adult brother and adult nephew would be sleeping in the room with one of
the foster children for safety due to the child’s behaviors, while she slept
upstairs. It further noted that the foster parent would “one on one” with one
foster child, while “the men will each one on one with” the other foster child.
7

APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.12309 Records check.
(1) An agency shall, upon receipt of an application, request
the department of state police to conduct both a criminal
history check and a criminal record check through the
federal bureau of investigation for applicants. The agency
shall also request the department to conduct a criminal
history check on all persons residing in the home over 18
years of age. Additional checks shall pertain to previous
licenses, and substantiated child abuse and neglect
records for all applicants and persons residing in the home
18 years of age or over in Michigan and in all states where
the applicant has resided in the 5 years preceding the
application.
ANALYSIS: The agency is in violation as the Licensing Supervisor became
aware of the adult brother staying/sleeping in the home when
the foster parent sent the Licensing Supervisor the safety plan,
on or about 03/04/21. The licensing Supervisor did not take
action on the home to correct this situation. Although the
Licensing Supervisor said she told the foster parent that the
adult brother could not provide care, she did not direct him to
leave the home until 03/26/21, or coordinate with the borrowed
bed foster care workers for the children in the home related to
their safety. Additionally, on 03/04/21, the foster parent advised
in the safety plan that her adult son and an adult nephew were
also staying in the home to help her. When asked about this, the
Licensing Supervisor said she was not sure who the nephew
was or how he was related. No clearances were provided as
documentation for these individuals who the Licensing
Supervisor was advised were staying in the home.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
ALLEGATION:
Agency allowed an adult household member to sleep in the same room with the
foster children and provide care and supervision.
INVESTIGATION:
See investigation notes above.
8

APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.12319 Substitute care policy.
An agency's substitute care policy shall, at a minimum,
contain provisions for all of the following:
(a) Qualifications for substitute caregivers, consistent
with the requirements of 1973 PA 116 and child care
licensing rules.
ANALYSIS: The agency is in violation as the foster parent was advised on
03/04/21, via the safety plan, that her adult son, adult brother,
and adult nephew were staying in the home to help her with the
children due to the intense behavior issues. The plan further
noted that the brother and nephew were sharing a sleeping
area, to provide care and supervision to one of the foster
children at night due to the child’s behaviors. Although the
Licensing Supervisor reported that she told the foster parent the
adult brother could not provide care due to his clearance, she
did not report addressing this situation in any other manner.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
ALLEGATION:
Staff also compromised a DHHS investigation in this same home. Concerns that
agency is not appropriately addressing issues through special evaluations of this
provider.
INVESTIGATION:
The complainant reported that a DHHS Specialist was assigned an investigation of
this foster parent on 03/25/21, and it was being completed jointly with the Licensing
Worker. The complainant noted that the Licensing Supervisor was also very involved
in this investigation. The complainant reported that the agency notified the foster
parent of the allegations prior to the DHHS worker being able to interview the foster
parent and expressed concern that the alleged perpetrator would coach the alleged
victim. It was alleged that the Licensing Worker initially said that the Licensing
Supervisor had shared the allegations. The DHHS Specialist reportedly met with the
Licensing Worker and Licensing Supervisor at the foster home on 03/26/2021, and
asked what exactly they told the alleged perpetrator. The Licensing Supervisor
reported that all they told the foster mother was that a DHHS complaint was received
and that someone would be following up with her. The complainant said that the
DHHS Specialist directly told the Licensing Supervisor that the foster care worker
said the allegations were already shared with the foster parent. The complainant
9

said that the Licensing Supervisor’s explanation was that the foster mother has a
right to know the allegations. The complainant acknowledged that the alleged
perpetrator has a right to know the allegations but said that the investigative process
should be coordinated with all involved. The complainant also alleged that the
Licensing Supervisor and Licensing Worker questioned the foster child after the joint
interviews were done and the DHHS Specialist had left the home. The complainant
said that during this additional questioning, the child recanted their report, but said it
in a manner that showed the child was coached. The complainant reported that at
the end of the joint interview of the child, the child disclosed that the foster parent
told him not to talk about the allegations. The child then disclosed that what was
alleged actually did happen.
During the LS interview on 04/14/21, the LS reported that she did tell the foster
parent about the complaint. The LS said that the licensing rules require notification
of the allegations within five days. The LS said that she had already talked to the
foster parent before she got notification of the DHHS Specialist being assigned and
had told her the allegations and that she would probably hear from DHHS. The LS
also said that she was not aware that they were not supposed to make the foster
parent notification, which is outlined in the Technical Assistance manual. The LS
reiterated this in a 04/19/21 email when she wrote, “The LW and I did not realize that
the foster parent should not have been advised until after the DHHS specialist had
indicated that information to us.” The LS said that she was at the home during the
interviews and did not question the youth after the DHHS Specialist left. The LS said
that the foster parent approached her and the LW and told the child to tell them why
he lied. The child then said he lied about what happened to get off punishment. The
LS said they did not continue to question the child.
I interviewed the Licensing Worker (LW) via video conference on 04/20/21. The LW
reported that she received an email related to a complaint on this foster home on
03/24/21 and about 20 minutes later received notification that DHHS was going to
investigate as well. The LW said that during a call from the foster parent on
03/25/21, where she and the LS were both on the call, the LS notified the foster
parent of the special investigation and the allegations. The LW said that the DHHS
Specialist called later on 03/25/21 and scheduled an unannounced home visit to
investigate the complaint on 03/26/21. The LW said that the DHHS Specialist
addressed the LW and LS on telling the foster parent about the allegations prior to
the interviews and advised them that on joint investigations they should wait until
they do the initial contact to notify in person, to try and prevent the children from
being coached or threatened. The LW, LS and DHHS Specialist went in the home
and conducted interviews. The LW said the LS stayed with the foster parent while
the children were being interviewed to ensure privacy. The LW said that during the
foster child’s interview, he said that the foster parent told him to tell the workers that
he was lying to get out of punishment. After the interviews, the LW said the DHHS
Specialist left. When the LW went back in the house, the foster parent directed the
foster child to tell them (the LW and the LS) why he was lying. The child said he lied
to get off punishment. The LW said the child shut down then and would not respond
10

to her like he had during his interview. The LW said that they had not reinterviewed
the youth, but the foster parent just directed him to say this.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.12206 Staff qualifications.
(1) An agency shall require that a staff member who has
ongoing contact with children or parents to be a person
who has the ability, experience, education, and training to
perform the duties assigned.
ANALYSIS: The agency is in violation of the rule as they reported that they
were not told of the adult brother staying in the home, however,
provided documentation (safety plan) that they were advised on
03/04/21. Specifically, they were advised that the adult son,
adult brother, and adult nephew were staying in the home and
that the brother and nephew would be sleeping in a room with
one of the foster children for safety, to provide supervision. No
action was taken by the Licensing Supervisor or Licensing
Worker related to this information and the adult brother was still
in the home through the end of March. The Licensing Supervisor
provided inconsistent information from her interview when
compared to her email and the provided documentation. The
Licensing Supervisor did not know who the nephew was or how
he was related. Neither the Licensing Supervisor nor Licensing
Worker reported addressing the sleeping situation in the home
or the adult household members residing there.
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE:
It has been established in the CPA Technical Assistance
manual for some time that licensing workers and CPAs are not
to advise foster parents of allegations of abuse/neglect when
working with DHHS until the day of the interview. Neither the
Licensing Worker nor Licensing Supervisor reported knowledge
of this. It is recommended, given violation and this TA that both
attend licensing complaint training again.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
11

ADDITIONAL FINDINGS:
During the course of this investigation, the agency provided their completed Special
Evaluation Report for review. The report condensed multiple intakes into one special
evaluation which is not the intention nor direction of the Department. In this case,
intakes were noted to have been received 03/03/2021 and two on 03/24/21. Multiple
allegations were made within these intakes, but the agency combined the special
evaluations into one report. Upon review, this Special Evaluation Report,
2021C0629544, did not contain sufficient information to support the findings. One
section referenced during a review of MiSACWIS information related to this Special
Evaluation Report, it was found that there were several uploaded documents of
notes and other supporting information. This information is required to be
summarized in the Special Evaluation Report to describe and support the findings
and not on separate documents. The report had no description of interviews with any
related parties upon which to base the findings or conclusions.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(1) An agency shall do all of the following when anyone in
the agency receives information that relates to possible
noncompliance with any foster home rule:
(c) Conduct a thorough investigation including all
necessary collateral contacts.
(5) Within 15 days of the conclusion of the evaluation, an
agency shall complete a written report that includes all of
the following information:
(a) The date the information was received.
(b) Identification of the information source, unless
anonymous or confidential, as specified in the child
protection law, 1975 PA 238, MCL 722.621 to 722.638.
(c) The allegations.
(e) Findings of fact, based upon the evaluation.
(f) Conclusions regarding licensing rules compliance
or noncompliance based on the findings of fact.
(g) Any change in the agency’s decision regarding
the number, gender, age, race, ethnic background,
and specific characteristics of children who may be
placed that is based upon the documentation
contained in the summary and conclusions of the
report.
12

ANALYSIS: The agency is in violation of the rule as they did not document a
thorough investigation of the allegations. They combined
multiple intake allegations, some received three weeks apart,
into one report and did not clearly identify all the allegations and
when they were received. CPS was identified in the report,
which is protected information and must be coded as DHHS.
The findings and conclusions are not supported by documented
facts and information, as the agency failed to include the
worker’s analysis of gathered information, or descriptions of
findings, observations and supporting documentation.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on the findings of this investigation, I recommend no change to the current
license status. This recommendation is contingent on the agency submitting an
acceptable corrective action plan for the noted violations.
June 08, 2021
________________________________________
Kari Muntean Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
June 14, 2021
________________________________________
Claudia Triestram Date
Area Manager
13
